title: What are the best bass strings for fretless? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are no “best bass strings for fretless”, just like there are no “best singers”. It is a matter of taste, and adaptability to your style. There have been “fretless” basses since Bach, but for electric fretless bass, you have to first look at the master:  Jaco is to fretless electric bass what George Washington is to American Presidents. You may argue that someone later was better, but he set the standard so high, it has taken us 240 years to throw that out the window. Jaco didn’t look at the fretless bass as a means to an end. He didn’t want to just go “Bwwawww”. He wanted to do whatever he wanted on bass unrestricted by the bounds of frets. He wanted freedom. Commonly, bassists use tapewound or flatwound strings on fretless basses, because it gives a muted “thump” to the sound and more closely apes the sound of a double bass. Jaco wanted the fretless to sing. So he used the brightest bass strings available at the time - the Rotosound 66 ″swing bass” strings:   They are roundwound strings, which increase the brightness and make the strings “slipperier” as the fingers skate across the top of the wind. I believe VERY strongly that these are the best strings possible for fretless. The sound is amazing and very very consistent. Some complain that the strings are hard on the hands, to which I say - “you are a bassist, suck it up”. Also, it is said that they are hard on the finish of the neck, which is why Jaco put a varnish on the neck. Bare wood fretless basses are in my mind, crazy dumb. It’s a steel string, people! Four strings, a board, and a couple of pickups. Heaven.

This is my bass (well, a google image of an identical one):  It’s a ’78 Precision fretless I’ve had since new. It’s the only bass I’ve every played extensively. I play mostly blues/rock and have always aspired to the Jaco sound. The bass has always been challenging to get a sound with. But when you get that sound, man it’s like nothing else. It’s powerful, punchy and really melodic. I’m mindful of neck-wear and could never bring myself to string it with round wounds and I don’t like the sound of flats so I’ve always used these:  They seem to be fairly easy on the neck (though I’ve refinished it a couple of times over the years) and they sound great. You can get an idea of what the bass sounds like on this: Brian's Bolero Edit: Actually this one is a better example of the bass’s sound: Summer of Bud
